title: Exercising with Fibromyalgia

content: When you’re in the midst of a fibromyalgia flare-up, the last thing you probably want to do is don spandex and get on a bike. Even going for a walk may seem like a daunting task. And perhaps you don’t know where to start.
You might’ve joined online groups or discussions about exercising with fibromyalgia and noticed that there are a lot of opinions out there. There’s a reason for that.
Everyone’s experience of this condition is different. What works for one person may not for another.
However, it’s universally agreed by medical professionals that exercise in any form is beneficial for managing fibromyalgia. From my experience, it’s actually essential.
A friend of mine, who’s a personal trainer, used three simple words that changed my perspective on exercise forever: “Movement is medicine.” How powerful is that?!

And he’s right. Some of my worst fibromyalgia flare-ups have been born from being inconsistent with moving my body. And if I skip workouts, I notice the difference. My aches and pains intensify and my energy dips.

content: I’ve come to realize that exercise doesn’t have to mean strenuous or grueling workouts. It can be anything that involves moving your body, from walking upwards. I’d say even cleaning your home counts!
When I was diagnosed, I’d spent 3 months on sick leave lying on the sofa and staring at the ceiling. I was so unwell I couldn’t brush my own hair.
On reflection, I was severely depressed too, which of course didn’t help. But I knew something had to change in order to feel better.
I realized pills or people wouldn’t fix me. I had to fix me.
After reading online about the benefits of exercise, I set mini challenges for myself, the first being to walk 5 minutes to the shop and back.

After repeating this several times and noticing it no longer felt difficult, I increased it to 10 minutes, and so on. Gradually increasing my activity meant my body didn’t go into shock (most of the time!).

content: Going outside and feeling part of the world again, being in nature and among people did wonders for my mental health. I started believing in myself.

Fast forward 4 years and I now do three to five hour-long workouts every week ranging from yoga to Pilates and boxing to cycling. I’m the fittest I’ve ever been and hold myself accountable to a 30-minute daily movement goal to ensure I don’t slip. For me, this discipline is self-love.

Patience and consistency are the two main ingredients for exercising when you live with fibromyalgia. You won’t see results right away, but when you do, it’s the best feeling in the world! Keep going and believing you’ll feel better.

Understanding what exercise suits your body is a process of trial and error. If you try something and it sends you into a flare-up, don’t be disheartened. You’re simply closer to figuring out what works for you.

content: Find what you enjoy and make it part of your daily life.

It’s really easy to fall into the trap of comparison with other people’s journeys. Avoid this at all costs. Treat yourself with compassion and kindness. Be prepared to fail and try again. Celebrate every small win along the way.
Exercise with fibromyalgia is as much a mental game as physical. So when you feel like giving up and your inner saboteur says, “I can’t,” ask yourself, “But what if I can?”
You’re stronger than you think. I believe in you.
